forkee.name: picasso
forkee.description: A powerful image downloading and caching library for Android

issue.title: BUG EXIF BitmapHunter.java L 557
issue.body:
Hey Guys, just wanted to let you know, that I found a bug in the current snapshot ( master branch ) in BitmapHunter.java line 557:

  int exifRotation = getExifRotation(exifOrientation); // exifRotation == 0
  int exifTranslation = getExifTranslation(exifOrientation); // exifTranslation == 1 // exifOrientation == 90
        if (exifRotation != 0) { <- NEVER reached
          matrix.preRotate(exifRotation);

The problem ist, that exifOrientation is already the value of the Rotation, in my case 90 Deg. 
getExifRotation on the other side is checking for the orientation value of the EXIF enum.
In other words : exifOrientation should be 6 instead of 90 for this code to work.

EDIT: The problem only occurs while selecting pictures from the Android Gallery. Pictures directly taken with the camera do not set the exifOrientation to the degreee value.
Camera Picture : exifOrientation = 6
Android Gallery : exifOrientation = 90

comment.body: I am also having the same problem. if exif orientation is deg, this code fails.


I expected Picasso to compress the image incase it was too large or atleast fail silently.

Thanks in advance.

issue.title: Should #placeholder(int) and #error(int) support theme attribute?
issue.body:
I mean in case we want some theme-depended drawable (vector, for example, which could be passed theme's color as attribute, not constant color value). By that a placeholder's drawable could be "lighter" in dark theme, and "darker" in light theme, dynamically. (IMO, caching a placeholder drawable is not necessary, as it doesn't consume too much resource).

The problem now is: Picasso will use a final ApplicationContext for its #getDrawable() action, which will not listen to theme's attributes.

Don't know if you are interested in theming and support libraries or not, but it would be nice if Picasso supports something like `ContextCompat.getDrawable()`.

comment.body:
> My workaround is to use there a distince Picasso instance
Hi @rekire, could you please share your workaround?

issue.title: Should #placeholder(int) and #error(int) support theme attribute?
issue.body:
I mean in case we want some theme-depended drawable (vector, for example, which could be passed theme's color as attribute, not constant color value). By that a placeholder's drawable could be "lighter" in dark theme, and "darker" in light theme, dynamically. (IMO, caching a placeholder drawable is not necessary, as it doesn't consume too much resource).

The problem now is: Picasso will use a final ApplicationContext for its #getDrawable() action, which will not listen to theme's attributes.

Don't know if you are interested in theming and support libraries or not, but it would be nice if Picasso supports something like `ContextCompat.getDrawable()`.

comment.body:
I'm using [picasso 3.0.0-alpha05](https://repo1.maven.org/maven2/com/squareup/picasso3/picasso/3.0.0-alpha05/), and this bug is still there.

I have a vector image in xml, and it uses certain colors. These colors are different in `values` and `values-night`. I set this vector image into `Picasso.placeholder(resId)`. I create a new instance of Picasso (using `Picasso.Builder(root.context).build()`) right in the `Adapter` class, and still this bug is still there.

If the system is using one mode (e.g. MODE_NIGHT_NO), but the app uses a different mode (e.g. MODE_NIGHT_YES) that was set using `AppCompatDelegate.setDefaultNightMode(...)` in `Application.onCreate` - this bug is there. Everything is OK if the system mode matches the mode set in the app.

I tried using same resource id for `Picasso.placeholder(resId)` and `Picassl.error(resId)`. It didn't work.

The only thing that worked for me is using `Picasso.placeholder(Drawable)` like `.placeholder(AppCompatResources.getDrawable(context, resId))`.

It's almost 2024, and this bug was around for so long. Dark mode support should be de facto by now. Please, have mercy!

pull_request.title: Add gif support to network requests
pull_request.body:
Uses ImageDecoder when available which already handles gifs and falls back to using the `android.graphics.Movie` API when < 28 with a custom Drawable for rendering. 


https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/672316/204376251-37543b2a-b9d7-499c-ba16-96bfc4853aaf.mov
